lead_paragraph: The seven-week military campaign in Afghanistan has given the world a stark view of a new American doctrine to make war on the sources of terrorism in the world. But with the defeat of the Taliban perhaps only days away and the hunt for Osama bin Laden intensifying, the force of the American destruction of Afghan targets has sent an unambiguous warning far beyond the war theater to a number of nations that continue to provide bases and training to terrorist groups. The warning is: this could happen to you. Yet how President Bush takes the war campaign from phase one in Afghanistan to phase two against Al Qaeda and other ''global reach'' terrorist groups in dozens of other countries remains an unsettled and, in some quarters, an unsettling question.
abstract: Pres Bush's next move in war against Al Qaeda and other 'global reach' terrorist groups in dozens of other countries remains unsettled and unsettling question as defeat nears for Taliban in Afghanistan; deep reservations exist among allies in Europe, Mideast and Russia over push by some in Bush administration to expand military operations to other nations and topple Pres Saddam Hussein of Irraq; pulverizing effect of first phase of war in Afghanistan signals Bush favors innovative tactics that quickly exploit enemy weaknesses with ruthless air attacks under doctrine in which use of force is unrestrained by borders or allies (M)
